text: LC 117 0957 S. R. 290- 1 -Senate Resolution 290By:  Senators James of the 35th, Tate of the 38th, Seay of the 34th, Anderson of the 43rd,  Butler of the 55th and others A RESOLUTIONRecognizing and commending Harriett Bryant; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, a beloved daughter of Richard and Bernice Powell, Harriett Bryant grew up in Atlanta and has long been known as one of the most dynamic and dedicated business leaders in the State of Georgia; and4WHEREAS, she is a graduate of Sheffield School of Aeronautics and worked as a flight controller for 13 years before embarking on a successful career in small business; and WHEREAS, Harriett credits meeting her husband, Ronald, as the spark that ignited her glowing record of entrepreneurship, as demonstrated by her ownership of both the Grown Folks Cafe and the 50 Yard Line Sports Bar; and9WHEREAS, over the course of her 24 years in business, Harriett has created many jobs in her community and has established a place in which community members of both Fulton and Clayton counties can relax and enjoy time with friends and family; and WHEREAS, Harriett is forever bonded to her community, her love of service to her neighbors, and her dedication to success, but her daughter, Ragan, is the most significant light in her life; and15WHEREAS, it is abundantly fitting and proper that the innumerable contributions of this magnificent business leader be appropriately recognized. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE that the members of this body recognize and commend Harriett Bryant for her 24 years of service as a business owner and extend sincere best wishes for continued success.20 19LC 117 0957 S. R. 290- 2 -BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Secretary of the Senate is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of this resoluti on available for distribution to Harriett Bryant.22

LC 39 2516 H. B. 1135- 1 -House Bill 1135By: Representatives Jackson of the 64 th, Hopson of the 153 rd, Smyre of the 135 th, Hugley of the 136th, and Boddie of the 62nd A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Code Section 40-2-86 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to special license plates promoting or supporting certain worthy agencies, funds, or nonprofit corporations with proceeds disbursed to the general fund and the agency, fund, or nonprofit corporation, so as to establish a specialty license plate honoring Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc.; to provide for related matters; to provide for compliance with constitutional requirements; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes. BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:7SECTION 1.8Code Section 40-2-86 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to special license plates promoting or supporting certain worthy  agencies, funds, or nonprofit corporations with proceeds disbursed to the general fund and  the agency, fund, or nonprofit corporation, is amended by adding a new paragraph to subsection (l) to read as follows: (64)  A special license plate honoring Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc.  The funds raised by the sale of this special license plate shall be disbursed to the Alpha Georgia Education Foundation, Inc.15SECTION 2.16In accordance with the requirements of Article III, Section IX, Paragraph VI(n) of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, this Ac t shall not become law unless it receives the requisite two-thirds' majority vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. SECTION 3.20All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed.21

LC 119 0041 S. R. 47- 1 -Senate Resolution 47By:  Senators Unterman of the 45th and Albers of the 56th  A RESOLUTIONCommending and congratulating Suwanee Police Chief Michael S. Jones as the 2018-2019 Georgia Police Chief of the Year; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, Suwanee Police Chief Michael S. Jones is highly regarded by the citizens of his community and state and by local government officials as a person of unquestioned integrity, humility and dedication to the sound principles of law enforcement; and WHEREAS, he began his career in 1974, following  in the footsteps of his father with the City of Rome Police Department, beginning  as a radio operator and rising to the rank of Major where he supervised the Field Operations, Support Services, and Administrative Services Bureaus; and9WHEREAS, Chief Jones earned a Bachelor of Arts from Berry College and Masters of Public Administration from Columbus College; and WHEREAS, Chief Jones graduated from the 155th Session of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's National Academy; and WHEREAS, he has served as chief of police  for the City of Suwanee Police Department, a full service and revered law enforcement agency, for the last 20 years; and WHEREAS, Chief Jones served as president of the Georgia Association of Chiefs of Police (GACP) in 2008-2009; and17WHEREAS, as chief he led the department to become State Certified through the GACP and Nationally Accredited with Excellence by the Commission on Accreditation for Law Enforcement (CALEA); and LC 119 0041 S. R. 47- 2 -WHEREAS, during his tenure, the department received national recognition for an innovative program known as Police and Citizens Together (PACT) in which officers are assigned as liaisons with different areas of the community to ensure the citizens' needs are being met and has been instrumental to lowering crime throughout the community; and WHEREAS, Chief Jones is united in love and marriage to Debbie Anne, who is also a law enforcement professional, for more than 40 years; and WHEREAS, it is abundantly fitting and proper that the members of this body show their gratitude for the unique and often unheralded contributions of Chief Jones and all local law enforcement officers on behalf of the citizens of this state. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE that the members of this body commend the care, courage, and selfless dedication exhibited by Suwanee Police Chief Michael S. Jones in carrying  out the difficult duties of his vocation and congratulate him upon his recognition as the 2018-2019 Georgia Police Chief of the Year.33BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Secretary of the Senate is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of this resolution available for distribution to Suwanee Police Chief Michael S. Jones.36

LC 47 0570 S. B. 519- 1 -Senate Bill 519By:  Senators Williams of the 39th, Jordan of the 6th, Jones II of the 22nd, Parent of the  nd, Anderson of the 43rd and others A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Code Section 1-4-1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to public and legal holidays and leave for observance of religious holidays not specifically provided2for, so as to designate June 19 of each year as a state holiday of Juneteenth; to remove June 3 as a potential state holiday; to provide for rela ted matters; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.5BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:6SECTION 1.7Code Section 1-4-1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to public and legal holidays and leave fo r observance of religious holidays not specifically provided for, is amended by revising subsections (a) and (b) as follows: (a)  The State of Georgia shall recognize and observe as public and legal holidays:11(1)  All days which have been designated as of January 1, 1984, as public and legal holidays by the federal government; and (2)  June 19 of each year, to be designated Juneteenth; and14(3)  All other days designated and proclaimed by the Governor as public and legal holidays or as days of fasting and prayer or other religious observance.  In such designation, the Governor shall include at least one of the following dates: January 19, or April 26, or June 3,  or a suitable date in lieu thereof to commemorate the event or events now observed by such dates.19(b)  The Governor shall close all state offices and facilities a minimum of 12 days throughout the year and not more than 12 days in observance of the public and legal holidays and other days set forth in subsection (a) of this Code section and shall specify the days state offices and facilities shall be closed for such observances.23SECTION 2.24All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed.25

LC 34 5551 S. R. 325- 1 -Senate Resolution 325By:  Senators Parent of the 42nd, Dugan of the 30th, Mullis of the 53rd, Kirkpatrick of the32nd, Williams of the 39th and others  A RESOLUTIONCreating the Senate Study Committee on Portable Benefits for Independent Workers; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, the nature of the economy and the workforce is rapidly changing, resulting in traditional employment relationships becoming less common; and WHEREAS, there is growing recognition that most policies supporting employee benefits are still tied to a model of traditional full-time employment; and WHEREAS, as more Georgians engage in temporary, contract, on-demand or other alternative work arrangements, there is a need to evaluate how these independent workers can access benefits and protections commonly provided to traditional full-time employees; and10WHEREAS, portable benefit models provide employee benefits outside the traditional employment relationship and allow independent workers to carry benefits with them from job to job or project to project; and13WHEREAS, there is an increasing awareness and interest in Georgia's business community regarding portable benefit models and their potential role in encouraging innovation, entrepreneurship, and a modern economy; and WHEREAS, it would be beneficial to study the usefulness and implementation of portable benefits in order to determine the most effective way to structure employment benefits to support a more independent 21st century workforce. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE:20(1)  Creation of Senate study committee. There is created the Senate Study Committee on Portable Benefits for Independent Workers.22 19LC 34 5551 S. R. 325- 2 -(2)  Members and officers. The committee shall be composed of five members of the Senate to be appointed by the President of the Senate. The President shall designate a member of the committee as chairperson of the committee. (3)  Powers and duties. The committee shall undertake a study of the conditions, needs, issues, and problems mentioned above or related thereto and recommend any action or legislation which the committee deems necessary or appropriate. (4)  Meetings.  The chairperson shall call all meetings of the committee. The committee may conduct such meetings at such places and  at such times as it may deem necessary or convenient to enable it to exercise fully and effectively its powers, perform its duties, and accomplish the objectives and purposes of this resolution. (5)  Allowances and funding.33(A)  The legislative members of the committee shall receive the allowances provided for in Code Section 28-1-8 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated.35(B)  The allowances authorized by this resolution shall not be received by any member of the committee for more than five days unless additional days are authorized.  Funds necessary to carry out the provisions of this resolution shall come from funds appropriated to the Senate.39(6)  Report.40(A)  In the event the committee adopts any specific findings or recommendations that include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file a report of the same prior to the date of abolishment specified in this resolution, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.44(B)  In the event the committee adopts a re port that does not include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file the report, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.47(C)  No report shall be filed unless the same has been approved prior to the date of abolishment specified in this resolution by majority vote of a quorum of the committee. A report so approved shall be signed by the chairperson of the committee and filed with the Secretary of the Senate.51(D)  In the absence of an approved report, the chairperson may file with the Secretary of the Senate a copy of the minutes of the meetings of the committee in lieu thereof. (7)  Abolishment.  The committee shall stand abolished on December 1, 2019.

LC 120 0225 H. R. 1096- 1 -House Resolution 1096By: Representatives Clark of the 108th, Hutchinson of the 107th, and Gambill of the 15 th A RESOLUTIONRecognizing and commending Laura Ross, the American School Counselor Association's School Counselor of the Year; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, a proper quality education for the young people of this state is the single most important objective of the General Assembly; and WHEREAS, nothing is more vital to the future of our state than the education of our young people, and Laura Ross exemplifies the selfless dedication that is characteristic of our finest school faculty; and7WHEREAS, since 2014, Laura ha s been a highly praise d counselor at Five Forks Middle School in Lawrenceville, Georgia. She tirelessly directs an extraordinary amount of time and talent toward building relationships with students and helping them achieve their full potential; and11WHEREAS, Laura Ross is the founder of the Five Forks Middle School Gay Straight Alliance, a cadre trainer for the Dove Self-Esteem Project, and the middle school chair of the district's Counseling Steering Committee; and WHEREAS, she has earned the admiration of her colleagues as a result of her dedication to the students of Five Forks Middle School and has been honored as the American School Counselor Association's 2020 School Counselor of the Year; and WHEREAS, in recognition of such remarkable contributions to the welfare of Georgia's students, it is abundantly fitting and proper that the extraordinary efforts of this outstanding counselor be honored.20NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES that the members of this body recognize and commend Laura Ross for being named the American LC 120 0225 H. R. 1096- 2 -School Counselor Association's 2020 School Counselor of the Year and extend their most sincere best wishes for continued success.24BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of this resolution available for distribution to Laura Ross.27

LC 121 0305 H. R. 1278- 1 -House Resolution 1278By: Representatives Jackson of the 128 th, Efstration of the 104 th, Williams of the 168 th, Smyre of the 135th, and Boddie of the 62nd A RESOLUTIONCommending Beauty Poole Baldwin, Georgia's first black school superintendent; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, a proper quality education for the young people of this state is the single most important objective of the General Assembly; and WHEREAS, Beauty Poole Baldwin is a highly praised educator and administrator in Georgia, tirelessly directing an extraordinary amount of time and talent toward guiding students to a brighter future; and7WHEREAS, Beauty is the beloved daughter of Sammie George Poole Sr. and Beurena Poole; and9WHEREAS, in 1984, she was named superintendent of Buford City Schools after working numerous teaching jobs at the John Lewis High School, Hardaway High, Central Gwinnett High School, and serving as the principal of Buford Middle School; and12WHEREAS, within the Gwinnett County School System, she taught math, served as coordinator of vocational academic education, and worked as assistant principal at Central Gwinnett High School; and15WHEREAS, Beauty attended Savannah State College and received a bachelor's degree in mathematics; she then attended the University of Georgia, where  she obtained a master's degree in vocational education and a VE-5 in vocational administration; and WHEREAS, Beauty's legacy was honored in 2016 when the Gwinnett County Board of Education officially dedicated Baldwin Elementary School in her name; and LC 121 0305 H. R. 1278- 2 -WHEREAS, in recognition of such remarkable contributions to the education and welfare of Georgia's students, it is abundantly fitting and proper to honor the extraordinary accomplishments and academic achievements of this outstanding Georgian. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES that the members of this body commend Beauty Poole Baldwin for her trailblazing accomplishments as Georgia's first black school superintendent and express their most sincere best wishes for continued success.27BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of this resolution available for distribution to Beauty Poole Baldwin.30

LC 33 7834 H. B. 558- 1 -House Bill 558By: Representatives Jones of the 25 th, Stovall of the 74 th, Cantrell of the 22 nd, and Gambill of the 15th A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Code Section 20-2-2081 of the Offici al Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to definitions relative to state charter schools, so  as to provide that state charter schools with state-wide attendance zones are considered to have state-wide jurisdiction for certain purposes; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.4BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:5SECTION 1.6Code Section 20-2-2081 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to definitions7relative to state charter schools, is amended by revising paragraph (1) as follows: (1)  'Attendance zone' means all or a portion of a local school system, one or more local school systems or portions thereof, or all local school systems in this state.  A state charter school with an attendance zone that includes all local school systems in this state shall be considered to have state-wide jurisdiction as that term is used in Chapter 14 of Title 50.13SECTION 2.14All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed.15

LC 117 0785 S. R. 117- 1 -Senate Resolution 117By:  Senators Jones of the 25th, Black of the 8th, Beach of the 21st, Brass of the 28th and  Parent of the 42nd A RESOLUTIONHonoring the life and memory of Dawson Heath; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, the State of Georgia mourns the lo ss of one of its most distinguished citizens with the passing of Dawson Heath on December 31, 2018; and WHEREAS, Dawson Heath was a beloved citizen of Jackson, Georgia, and he dedicated his life to improving the city as a firefighter and street department superintendent; and WHEREAS, he diligently and conscientiously devoted innumerable hours of his time, talents, and energy toward the betterment of his community and state as evidenced dramatically by his superlative service with the City of Jackson for 35 years; and WHEREAS, he gave inspiration to many through his high ideals, morals, and deep concern for his fellow citizens, and the devotion, patience, and understanding he demonstrated to his family and friends were admired by others; and WHEREAS, he was a person of magnanimous strengths with an unimpeachable reputation for integrity, intelligence, fairness, and kindness, and by the example he made of his life, he made this world a better place in which to live; and WHEREAS, a compassionate and generous man, Dawson will long be remembered for his love of family, friendship, and community  and will be missed by all who had the great fortune of knowing him. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE that the members of this body join in honoring the life and memory of Dawson Heath and express their deepest and most sincere regret at his passing.20 19LC 117 0785 S. R. 117- 2 -BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Secretary of the Senate is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of this resolution available for distribution to the family of Dawson Heath.23

LC 117 1237 H. R. 803- 1 -House Resolution 803By: Representative Burnough of the 77th A RESOLUTIONRecognizing and commending the Atlanta Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc., on the grand occasion of its 40th anniversary; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, the Atlanta Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc., has a long and consistent record of service to the community and this state and has been recognized as one of the most dynamic and committed civic organizations in Georgia; and WHEREAS, this organization's mission is to inspire its members to a high moral, intellectual, social, and civic standing and to promote and sponsor social, cultural, literacy, and charitable affairs; and8WHEREAS, the inception of the Atlanta Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc., emerged from an existing friendship between Peggy Burke of the Columbus, Ohio, Chapter and Inez Hill of Atlanta, Georgia; these two inspired young women were instrumental in organizing the Atlanta Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc., sponsored by the Columbus Chapter; and WHEREAS, the Atlanta Chapter was very instrumental in the sponsorship of the Decatur Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc., November 9, 2009, and the Decatur Chapter held their first National Conclave in June, 2018; and15WHEREAS, the Atlanta Chapter held its firs t conclave in June, 1989, and the second one in June, 2012; and17WHEREAS, the Atlanta Chapter has grown over its 40 years of community service, making annual contributions to the Sickle Cell Foundation, donating stocking stuffers and Thanksgiving baskets to needy families, providing clothing and gifts to My Sister's House and Dress for Success, and making yearly contributions to the United Negro College Fund; and22 19LC 117 1237 H. R. 803- 2 -WHEREAS, it is abundantly fitting and proper  that the outstanding contributions of this magnificent civic organization be appropriately recognized. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES that the members of this body recognize and commend the Atlanta Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc., on the grand occasion of its 40th anniversary and extend the most sincere best wishes for continued growth, development, and success. BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of th is resolution available for distribution to the Atlanta Chapter of National Epicureans, Inc.31

LC 121 0235 H. R. 1129- 1 -House Resolution 1129By: Representative Dollar of the 45th A RESOLUTIONCommending and congratulating Dipen Meht a upon receiving a 2020 Prudential Spirit of Community Award; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, Dipen, an esteemed resident of Marietta, Georgia, and a senior at Riverwood International Charter School, has achieved national recognition and has been honored with a 2020 Prudential Spirit of Community Award for her exemplary volunteer service; and WHEREAS, this prestigious award, presented by  Prudential Financial in partnership with the National Association of Secondary School Principals, honors young volunteers across America who have demonstrated an extraordin ary commitment to serving their communities; and9WHEREAS, Dipen earned this award by giving gene rously of her time and energy to founded a nonprofit organization in 2017 that now encompasses more than 100 young people in several states and overseas who are working to improve the lives of children in need, particularly in the areas of nutrition, sanitation, and education; and13WHEREAS, the success of the State of Georgia, the strength of our communities, and the overall vitality of American society depend, in great measure, upon the dedication of young people like Dipen who choose to use their considerable talents and resources to serve others. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES that the members of this body commend Dipen Mehta for her outstanding record of volunteer service, peer leadership, and community spirit and congratulate her upon receiving a 2020 Prudential Spirit of Community Award. BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of th is resolution available for distribution to Dipen Mehta.23

LC 119 0143 S. R. 110- 1 -Senate Resolution 110By:  Senators Heath of the 31st, Gooch of the 51st, Mullis of the 53rd, Harper of the 7th,  Tillery of the 19th and others A RESOLUTIONRecognizing February 20, 2019, as the 7th Annual Legislative Fly-In at the state capitol and commending the Georgia Airports Association and its leadership; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, Georgia's airport system is an extremely important and valuable transportation resource for this state's residents, businesses, visitors, and recreational aviators; and WHEREAS, the mission of the Georgia Airports Association is "to provide, develop, and expand a safe and efficient airports system to meet the future economic growth of Georgia through the full implementation of the State Aviation System Plan"; and WHEREAS, the State Aviation System Plan recognizes that airports are an indispensable component of this state's total transportation system that strongly supports this state's economy; and WHEREAS, Georgia Airports Association President Tom Strong, former President Kevin Britton, Vice President Lenard Robinson, Treasurer Mike Mathews, Legislative Chair Mario Evans, and Secretary Robert Burr have diligently and conscientiously worked to obtain the maximum amount of financial support they can for every airport in Georgia, regardless of size or type; and15WHEREAS, the Georgia Airports Association' s expansive networking organization provides16a forum where questions can be asked and wh ere answers and documents can be shared by individuals, allowing smaller airfields to accomplish much more in a limited period of time with the money and resources available; and WHEREAS, it is abundantly fitting and proper to recognize the vital role that these airports play in connecting their areas to the aviation  system for their region, this state, and the nation.22 19LC 119 0143 S. R. 110- 2 -NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE that the members of this body recognize February 20, 2019, as the 7th Annual Legi slative Fly-In at the state capitol and commend the Georgia Airports Association and its leadership, Tom Strong, Kevin Britton, Lenard Robinson, Mike Mathews, Mario Evans, Jim Galloway, Kim Wade, and Jason Pinnix for their dedicated service to the State of Georgia.27BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Secretary of the Senate is authorized and directed28to make an appropriate copy of this resolution available for distribution to the Georgia Airports Association.30

LC 41 1739 H. B. 236- 1 -House Bill 236By: Representatives Bruce of the 61st, Bazemore of the 63 rd, McLeod of the 105th, Jacksonof the 64th, Trammell of the 132 nd, and others A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Chapter 11 of Title 31 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to emergency medical services, so as to provide that first responders of municipal fire departments may engage in the emergency medical transportation of patients; to revise findings and a declaration of policy concerning first responders in this state; to revise and provide for definitions; to provide that first responders of a fire department of a municipality shall be granted licenses for emergency medical transportation under certain circumstances; to revise the Emergency Medical Systems Communications Program (EMSC Program); to provide for rules and regulations; to provide for licensing; to provide for related matters; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.9BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:10SECTION 1.11Chapter 11 of Title 31 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to emergency medical services, is amended in Code Section 31-11-1, relating to findings and declaration of policy, by revising paragraph (6) of subsection (a) as follows:14(6)  Any first responder falls under the department's rules and regulations governing ambulances and can transport only in life-threatening situations or by orders of a licensed physician or when a licensed ambulance cannot respond may engage in the emergency medical transportation of patients as provided for in this chapter SECTION 2.19Said chapter is further amended in Code Section 31-11-2, relating to definitions, by revising paragraphs (1.2) and (10) and by adding a new paragraph to read as follows:21(1.2)  'Ambulance' means a motor vehicle that is specially constructed and equipped or an air ambulance and is intended to be used for the emergency transportation of patients, including emergency medical service motor vehicles of fire departments, dual purpose LC 41 1739 H. B. 236- 2 -police patrol cars and funeral coaches, or hearses which otherwise comply with the provisions of this chapter.26(9.1)  'Fire department' shall have the same meaning as provided for in Code Section (10)  'First responder' means any person or agency who that provides on-site care until:29(A)  Until the arrival of a duly licensed ambulance service; or (B)  Upon the emergency medical transportation of patients by such person or agency acting as an ambulance service SECTION 3.33Said chapter is further amended by adding a new Code section to read as follows: (a)  The department shall grant a license fo r emergency medical transportation to a first responder if such first responder:37(1)  Is of a fire department of a municipality; and (2)  Meets the same applicable training and standards criteria established by the department for the provision of ambulance services. (b)  When a first responder has obtained a license for emergency medical transportation as provided for under subsection (a) of this Code section, such first responder shall administer the emergency medical services system for the geographical area covering its jurisdiction and may contract with licensed ambulance providers to supplement such first responder's coverage of such geographical area.45(c)  A first responder that obtains a license for emergency medical transportation shall be authorized to bill patients and to recover fees , expenses, and administrative costs associated with such emergency medical transportation conducted by the first responder. SECTION 4.49Said chapter is further amended in Code Section 31-11-3, relating to recommendations by local coordinating entity as to administration of EMSC Program and hearing and appeal, by revising subsection (a) as follows:52(a)  The Board of Public Health shall have th e authority on behalf of the state to designate and contract with a public or nonprofit local en tity to coordinate and administer the EMSC Program for each health district, or  the parts of each health district, designated by the Department of Public Health that is not within the geographical area of a first responder having a license for emergency medical transportation as provided for in Code Section The local coordinating entity thus designated shall be responsible for recommending to the board or its designee the manner in which the EMSC Program is to LC 41 1739 H. B. 236- 3 -be conducted.  In making its recommendations, the local coordinating entity shall give priority to making the EMSC Program function as efficiently and economically as possible. Each licensed ambulance provider in the health district shall have the opportunity to participate in the EMSC Program. SECTION 5.64Said chapter is further amended in Code Section 31-11-5, relating to rules and regulations, by revising subsection (a) as follows:66(a)  The department is authorized to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the protection of the public health:68(1)  Prescribing reasonable health, sanitation, and safety standards for transporting patients in ambulances; (2)  Prescribing reasonable conditions under which ambulance attendants or first responders are required;72(3)  Establishing criteria for the training of ambulance attendants and first responders that engage in the emergency medical transportation of patients ; and74(4)  Establishing that The emergency medical technician course is courses are to be offered at area hospitals and area technical vocational schools in conjunction with their emergency patient care and personnel training programs. SECTION 6.78Said chapter is further amended by revising Code Section 31-11-6, relating to records, as follows:8031-11-6.81(a)  Records of each ambulance trip shall be made by the ambulance service in a manner and on such forms as may be prescribed by the department through regulations.  Such records shall be available for inspection by the department at any time, and a summary of ambulance service activities shall be prepared on specific cases and furnished to the department upon request. (b)  Records of each first responder trip wherein the emergency medical transportation of a patient has occurred shall be made by the pe rson or agency that provides on-site care in a manner and on such forms as may be prescribed by the department through regulations. Such records shall be available for inspection by the department at any time, and a summary of such emergency medical transportation activities shall be prepared in specific cases and furnished to the department upon request. LC 41 1739 H. B. 236- 4 -SECTION 7.93Said chapter is further amended by adding a new Code section to read as follows: No first responder shall engage in the emergency medical transportation of patients without having a valid license issued by the license officer for such purpose.  Such license shall conform to the requirements and standards provided for an ambulance service pursuant to this chapter.99SECTION 8.100Said chapter is further amended in Code Section 31-11-53.1, relating to automated external defibrillator program, establishment, regulations, and liability, by revising paragraph (3) of subsection (a) as follows:103(3)  'First responder' means any person or agency who that provides on-site care until:104(A)  Until the arrival of a duly licensed ambulance service; or (B)  Upon the emergency medical transportation of patients by such person or agency acting as an ambulance service This shall include, but not be limited to, persons who or agencies that routinely respond to calls for assistance through an affiliation with law enforcement agencies, fire suppression agencies, rescue agencies, and others.110SECTION 9.111All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed.112

LC 34 5506 H. B. 350- 1 -House Bill 350By: Representative Williamson of the 115 th A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Code Section 48-7-40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to tax credits for certain business enterprises located in certain counties, so as to change the carry forward provisions relating to such credit; to provide for conditions and limitations; to provide for related matters; to provide for an effective date and applicability; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.5BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:6SECTION 1.7Code Section 48-7-40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to tax credits for certain business enterprises located in certain counties, is amended by revising subsection (h) as follows:10(h)(1)  Any credit claimed under this Code section, prior to July 1, 2019, but not used in any taxable year may be carried forward for ten years from the close of the taxable year in which the qualified jobs were established,.13(2)  Any credit claimed under this Code section on or after July 1, 2019, but not used in any taxable year, may be carried forward for  ten years from the close of the taxable year in which the credit or credit installment was claimed. The credit established by this Code section is subject to forfeiture as provided in paragraph (1) of subsection (e) of this Code section, but in tiers 3 and 4 the credit established by this Code section taken in any one taxable year shall be limited to an amount not greater than percent of the taxpayer's state income  tax liability which is attributable to income derived from operations in this state for that taxable year.  In tier 1 and 2 counties, the credit allowed under this Code section agains t taxes imposed under this article in any taxable year shall be limited to an amount not greater than 100 percent of the taxpayer's state income tax liability attributable to income derived from operations in this state for such taxable year.25 19LC 34 5506 H. LC 28 9479 H. LC 34 5572S H.R. 228 (SUB)- 1 -The House Committee on Judiciary offers the following substitute to HR 228: A RESOLUTIONUrging the President of the United States and the United States Congress to enact legislation securing the citizenship of internationally adopted adult individuals; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, the Child Citizenship Act of  aimed to provide equal treatment under United States law for adopted and biological children by granting citizenship to internationally born adoptees; however, when the act became law, it did not apply to internationally born adoptees who were already over the age of 18, those with legal adoptions who entered on visas requiring a secondary readoption in the United States, and those who were adopted legally abroad  or here by United States citi zens but entered the country on nonimmigrant visas; and WHEREAS, as a result, an estimated tens of thousands of adult legal adoptees of United States citizens who were born before February 27, 1982, and raised in the United States are still undocumented, and therefore potentially subject to possible deportation; these adoptees' parents did not complete necessary processes to provide their adopted children with citizenship or, in many cases, even a green card; and WHEREAS, several deportations of individuals who were legally adopted by United States citizens have already taken place, breaking up and returning the deported individuals to places where they were born but have no family, language ability,  means to support themselves, or other connections and are at risk of homelessness, poverty, and mental health challenges or death; and19WHEREAS, adoptees who do not have citizensh ip have come from countries such as Argentina, Brazil, China, Colombia, Costa Rica, Germany, Guatemala, El Salvador, India, Ireland, Haiti, Iran, Japan, Mexico, Panama, Philippines, Russia, St. Kitts, Taiwan, Ukraine, and Vietnam; there are an estimated 20,000  Korean American a doptees alone who do not have American citizenship despite having been legally adopted; and LC 34 5572S H.R. 228 (SUB)- 2 -WHEREAS, two bills which would grant citizenship to adult adoptees were introduced with bipartisan support in both the 114th and 115th C ongresses and have been reintroduced in the th Congress: the Adoptee Citizenship Act  of 2015 and 2018; neither bill was referred out of committee for a congressional vote; and WHEREAS, the bills sought to amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to grant automatic citizenship to all qualifying children adopted by a United States citizen parent, regardless of their ages; and31WHEREAS, upon enactment of the Adoptee Citizenship Act, qualifying individuals would automatically become United States citizens on the date on which the person is lawfully admitted to the United States, subject to passing a criminal background check; individuals convicted of offenses involving the use of physical force against other persons may not be granted automatic citizenship; and WHEREAS, naturalization of adult adoptees who immigrated to America under the promise of finding a permanent home is necessary to ensure that they are not forcibly removed from what has become their home country; and WHEREAS, the State of Georgia does not condone the deportation of individuals who were legally adopted into American homes and should  have every expectation  that their citizenship matches that of their adoptive parents; further, the State welcomes broad legislation that will provide a pathway to citizenship for all adult adoptees whose adoptive parents did not complete the naturalization process while they were children. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES that the members of this body urge the President of the United States and the United States Congress to enact legislation securing the citizenship of internationally adopted adult individuals.48BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make appropriate copies of this resolution available for distribution to the President of the United States and to each member of Congress from Georgia.

R. 233- 1 -Senate Resolution 233By:  Senators Orrock of the 36th, Butler of  the 55th, Karinshak of the 48th, Rahman of the th, Kirkpatrick of the 32nd and others A RESOLUTIONRecognizing October 9, 2019, as PANDAS Awareness  Day at the state capitol; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, pediatric acute-onset neuropsychiatric syndrome (PANS) and pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infection (PANDAS) create the sudden onset of obsessive-compulsive disorder, tic disorders, and/or restrictive eating in children, causing previously healthy and emotionally adjusted children to experience severe anxiety and emotional disturbances; and WHEREAS, children with PANS and PANDAS te nd to manifest some of the following symptoms: tics or other abnormal movements, severe separation anxiety, generalized anxiety, irritability, aggression, personality changes, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, marked deterioration in learning and school performance, and developmental regression, including regression in handwriting; and12WHEREAS, children with PANS and PANDAS may experience a moderate to dramatic improvement with antibiotics, intravenous immunoglobulin treatment, or plasmapheresis; and15WHEREAS, researchers at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) are currently engaged in extensive research and testing on how to effectively treat PANS and PANDAS; and18WHEREAS, researchers at Moleculera Labs at the University of Oklahoma have developed PANS and PANDAS blood testing procedures; and20WHEREAS, the University of Arizona and Banner Health System in Arizona have opened the first Centers for Post-Infectious Autoimm une Encephalopathy, providing insurance based LC 117 0856 S. R. 233- 2 -access to expert care and consultative services for general and subspecialist pediatricians around the country; and24WHEREAS, the deep medical and bioscience  resources in Georgia make our state well situated to meaningfully contribute to best medical practices, research, and medical technology to advance the early diagnosis and treatment of children with PANS and PANDAS; and28WHEREAS, the NIMH estimates one in 200 children have PANS or PANDAS, meaning these diseases affect roughly 15,000 children in Georgia; and30WHEREAS, many general pediatricians, nurse practitioners, and pediatric subspecialists are not familiar with the most current diagnostic criteria and treatment guidelines for these disorders; and33WHEREAS, in addition to lack of access to treating providers, many insurers do not cover treatment for PANS and PANDAS, which can cost many tens of thousands of dollars, placing it out of reach for most families; and WHEREAS, the Southeastern PANS/PANDAS Association is a Georgia based nonprofit organization dedicated to expanding access to expert, insurance based care for children and families suffering from PANS and PANDAS in this region; and WHEREAS, it is imperative that there be greater public awareness of this serious health issue among parents, policymakers, and medical providers in Georgia. R. 455- 1 -Senate Resolution 455By:  Senator Seay of the 34th A RESOLUTIONCreating the Senate Study Committee on Adult Changing Stations in Commercial Public Facilities; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS, the federal Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, while not stipulating adult changing stations, requires that specified buildings, structures, and facilities be accessible to, and usable by, individuals with disabilities; and5WHEREAS, as the number of individuals with disabilities continues to grow, the need for access to adult changing stations in commercial public facilities is becoming more apparent across our nation; and8WHEREAS, by expanding public restroom accommodations in large occupancy buildings such as auditoriums, convention centers, exhibition halls, sports arenas, and theaters, individuals with disabilities are given dignity and the basic human right to maintain their health; and12WHEREAS, special education departments in some areas of the country including California are providing changing stations for students so that they can comfortably and safely attend to their needs; and15WHEREAS, the private sector, including Disney California Adventure Park, offers adult changing stations in their facilities, and international airports such as Atlanta, Orlando, Baltimore/Washington, and Phoenix have installed adult changing stations to aid in the comfort and safety of their passengers; and WHEREAS, more states are considering requiring the installation and maintenance of adult changing stations in large commercial public facilities and certain state facilities, making it a timely and important topic for consideration and study by the State of Georgia. LC 46 0168 S. R. 455- 2 -NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE:23(1)  Creation of Senate study committee. There is created the Senate Study Committee on Adult Changing Stations in Commercial Public Facilities. (2)  Members and officers.  The committee shall be composed of five members of the Senate to be appointed by the President of  the Senate.  The President shall designate a member of the committee as chairperson of the committee. (3)  Powers and duties. The committee shall undertake a study of the conditions, needs, issues, and problems mentioned above or related thereto and recommend any action or legislation which the committee deems necessary or appropriate. (4)  Meetings.  The chairperson shall call all meetings of the committee.  The committee may conduct such meetings at such places and  at such times as it may deem necessary or convenient to enable it to exercise fully and effectively its powers, perform its duties, and accomplish the objectives and purposes of this resolution. (5)  Allowances and funding.36(A)  The legislative members of the committee shall receive the allowances provided for in Code Section 28-1-8 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated.38(B)  The allowances authorized by this resolution shall not be received by any member of the committee for more than five days  unless additional days are authorized.  Funds necessary to carry out the provisions of this resolution shall come from funds appropriated to the Senate.42(6)  Report.43(A)  In the event the committee adopts any specific findings or recommendations that include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file a report of the same prior to the date of abolishment  specified in this resolution, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.47(B)  In the event the committee adopts a report that does not include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file the report, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.50(C)  No report shall be filed unless the same has been approved prior to the date of abolishment specified in this resolution by majority vote of a quorum of the committee. A report so approved shall be signed by the chairperson of the committee and filed with the Secretary of the Senate.54(D)  In the absence of an approved report, the chairperson may file with the Secretary of the Senate a copy of the minutes of the meetings of the committee in lieu thereof. (7)  Abolishment.  The committee shall stand abolished on December 1, 2019.

B. 386- 4 -(vi)  Cystic fibrosis;100(vii)  Deafness;101(viii)  Down syndrome; (ix)  Drug or alcohol abuse;103(x)  Dual sensory impairment; (xi)  Dyslexia;105(xii)  Emotional or behavioral disorder; (xiii)  Epilepsy;107(xiv)  Hearing impairment; (xv)  Intellectual disability;109(xvi)  Muscular dystrophy;110(xvii)   Specific learning disability;111(xviii)  Spina bifida;112(xix)  Traumatic brain injury; (xx)  Visual impairment; or (xxi) Any rare disease identified by the National Institutes of Health™s Genetic and115Rare Disease Center's list of rare disease disorders. (4)  The parent obtains acceptance for admission of the student to a participating school; and118(5)  The parent submits an application for  a scholarship to the department no later than the deadline established by the department; provided, however, that the department shall provide application deadline opportunities on September 15, December 15, and February of each school year for a student to transfer.122(f)  With respect to local school systems, the acceptance Acceptance of a scholarship shall have the same effect as a parental refusal  to consent to services pursuant to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, 20 U.S.C.A. Section 1400, et seq., and  Section 504 of the federal Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C.A. Section 701, et seq.126SECTION 3.127Said article is further amended by revising subsection (a) of Code Section 20-2-2116, relating to amount of scholarship and method of payments, as follows: (a)  The maximum scholarship granted a scholarship student pursuant to this article shall be an amount equivalent to the costs of the educational program that would have been provided for the student in the resident school system as calculated under Code Section and, if a scholarship student has an Individualized Education Program,  based upon services specified in the Individualized E ducation Program in place at the time of the most recent enrollment count, as described in Code Section 20-2-160 This shall not SB 386/CSFA S. B. 386- 5 -include any federal funds.136SECTION 4.137Said article is further amended by revising  Code Section 20-2-2117, relating to adoption and promulgation of rules, immunity from liability for scholarship decisions, and schools barred from program participation for certain actions, as follows: (a)  The board shall adopt rules to administer the program regarding eligibility and participation of participating schools, including, but not limited to, timelines that will maximize student and public and private school participation, the calculation and distribution of scholarships to eligible students and participating schools, and the application and approval procedures for eligible students and participating schools.  The department shall develop and utilize a compliance form for completion by participating schools.  The department shall be authorized to require any pertinent information as it deems necessary from participating schools for the purpose of implementing the program. Participating schools shall be required to complete such forms and certify their accuracy. (b)  The board shall adopt rules to administer the program regarding student eligibility, transparency, and awareness of the impact of the program, including, but not limited to, the following:153(1)  The department shall conduct an annual survey of participating parents' satisfaction with the program, their satisfaction with the private school, and their likelihood of recommending the program.  Survey results shall be reported to the board and shall be subject to public review and comment; and (2)  The department shall post on its publicly accessible website the basic unit cost for general instructional programs, as a minimum estimate for scholarship amounts. B. 386- 6 -academic progress. (c)  No liability shall arise on the part of the  department or the state or of any local board of education based on the award or use of a scholarship awarded pursuant to this article.174(c)(d)  The department may bar a school from participation in the program if the department determines that the school has intentionally and substantially misrepresented information or failed to refund to the state any scholarship overpayments in a timely manner. LC 117 1088 S. R. 356- 1 -Senate Resolution 356By:  Senator Harbison of the 15th A RESOLUTIONCommending the Marion County girls basketball team for winning the 2019 GHSA-A state championship; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, the Marion County girls basketball t eam has established and maintained a proud tradition of excellence with equal emphases on character and academics; and WHEREAS, the team brought special recognition to its school and to Marion County by winning the 2019 GHSA-A state basketball championship against Calhoun County with a final score of 50 to 38; and7WHEREAS, the phenomenal performance of the team is a clear indication of the outstanding athletic ability, the dedication and hard work, and the unity of purpose and spirit of each member of the team under the astute direction of Head Coach Fran McPherson; and WHEREAS, this magnificent team performed with precision during the season and earned its well-deserved reputation for high standards of athletic achievement, the quality of its play, and the stiff competition it presented to its opponents. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE that the members of this body commend the Marion County girls basketball team for winning the 2019 GHSA-A state championship and extend their most sincere best wishes for continued success. BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Secretary  of the Senate is authorized and directed17to make an appropriate copy of this resolu tion available for distribution to the Marion County girls basketball team.

LC 48 0065 H. R. 329- 1 -House Resolution 329By: Representatives Boddie of the 62 nd, Bazemore of the 63 rd, Bruce of the 61 st, Jackson ofthe 64th, Alexander of the 66th, and others A RESOLUTIONCreating the House Study Committee on Home owners' Associations, Condominium Owners' Associations, and Property Owners in Community Associations; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, the real estate market has incr eased the number of properties available for purchase in various community associations; and WHEREAS, the property management trans itions in these comm unities lead to little guidance for property owners regarding the upkeep and maintenance of properties in such community associations; and WHEREAS, it would beneficial to study how these various communities could be better organized to implement requirements and procedures for turnover and transition from declarants, developers, or other establishing entities to property owners comprising the community association. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES:12(1)  Creation of House study committee. There is created the House Study Committee on Homeowners' Associations, Condominium Owners' Associations, and Property Owners in Community Associations. (2)  Members and officers.  The committee shall be composed of five members of the House of Representatives to be appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives.  The Speaker shall designate a member of the committee as chairperson of the committee. (3)  Powers and duties. The committee shall undertake a study of the conditions, needs, issues, and problems mentioned above or related thereto and recommend any action or legislation which the committee deems necessary or appropriate. (4)  Meetings.  The chairperson shall call all meetings of the committee.  The committee may conduct such meetings at such places and  at such times as it may deem necessary or LC 48 0065 H. R. 329- 2 -convenient to enable it to exercise fully and effectively its powers, perform its duties, and accomplish the objectives and purposes of this resolution. (5)  Allowances and funding.27(A)  The legislative members of the committee shall receive the allowances provided for in Code Section 28-1-8 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated.29(B)  The allowances authorized by this resolution shall not be received by any member of the committee for more than five days  unless additional days are authorized.  Funds necessary to carry out the provisions of this resolution shall come from funds appropriated to the House of Representatives.33(6)  Report.34(A)  In the event the committee adopts any specific findings or recommendations that include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file a report of the same prior to the date of abolishment specified in this resolution, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.38(B)  In the event the committee adopts a report that does not include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file the report, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.41(C)  No report shall be filed unless the same has been approved prior to the date of abolishment specified in this resolution by majority vote of a quorum of the committee. A report so approved shall be signed by the chairperson of the committee and filed with the Clerk of the House of Representatives.45(D)  In the absence of an approved report, th e chairperson may file with the Clerk of the House of Representatives a copy of the minutes of the meetings of the committee in lieu thereof.48(7)  Abolishment.  The committee shall stand abolished on December 1, 2019.

(c)  The municipal court may fix punishment for offenses within its jurisdiction not exceeding a fine of $1,000.00, imprisonment for 180 days, or both, or may fix punishment by fine, imprisonment, or alternative sentencing as now or hereafter provided by law. LC 28 9177 H. B. 537- 1 -House Bill 537By: Representatives Clark of the 98 th, Morris of the 26 th, Pruett of the 149 th, Jones of the 25 th,Cantrell of the 22nd, and others A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Chapter 2 of Title 21 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to elections and primaries generally, so as to provide that no voting device may be approved or provided for use in this state unless its final  assembly place was located in the United States; to provide a short title; to provide definitions; to provide sanctions; to provide an exception; to provide for related matters; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes. BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:6SECTION 1.7This Act shall be known as and may be cited as the "By America for America Act." SECTION 2.9Chapter 2 of Title 21 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to elections and primaries generally, is amended in Article 8A, relating to state-wide voting equipment, by adding a new Code section to read as follows:1221-2-301.13(a)  As used in this Code section, the term: (1)  'Final assembly place'  means the plant, factory, or other place at which a voting device is produced or assembled by a manufacturer and from which such voting device is delivered with all component mechanical parts necessary for the operation of such voting device.  Such term shall not include the location where approved software is uploaded to the voting device.19(2)  'Voting device' means any type of electronic, mechanical, or electromechanical apparatus on which an elector casts a vote, votes are tabulated, or ballots are marked. (b)  No voting device shall be approved, purchased, leased, or otherwise acquired for use in primaries or elections in this state unless its final assembly place is located in the United States.24 19LC 28 9177 H. B. 537- 2 -(c)  It shall be illegal for a person to execute  a contract to sell, lease, or otherwise provide a voting device that the person knows fails to satisfy the requirements of this Code section. A person convicted of violating this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature.28(d)  Nothing in this Code section shall pr ohibit a person from exhibiting a voting device that does not satisfy the requirements of this Code section. SECTION 3.31All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are repealed.32

R. 175- 2 -BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make an appropriate copy of this resolution available for distribution to Coach Thomas "T" McFerrin.

LC 121 0285 Senate Resolution 789By: Senators Harper of the 7th, Ginn of the 47th, Wilkinson of the 50th and Black of the 8th A RESOLUTIONCommending the Alpha Eta and Gamma Delta chapters of Alpha Gamma Rho and recognizing Friday, February 21, 2020, as Alpha Gamma Rho Day at the state capitol; and for other purposes.3WHEREAS, the purposes of Alpha Gamma Rho are to make better men by promoting influences that encourage individual effort and resourcefulness; to foster the development of better mental, social, moral, and physical qualities; and to promote a community of agricultural men through fellowship in a national organization that supports the best social, mental, and moral development; and WHEREAS, members of Alpha Gamma Rho are motivated to unite as men pursuing careers in agriculture, to present a positive attitude toward fellow agricultural students, to lend assistance to others when needed, and to bring out the best qualities in one another; and11WHEREAS, Alpha Gamma Rho was founded nationally on April 4, 1908, by two local fraternities from The Ohio State University and the University of Illinois; and WHEREAS, there are currently 72 active chapters throughout the nation, over 3,100 undergraduate members, and 75,000 total initiates; and WHEREAS, there are two cha pters of Alpha Gamma Rho in Georgia.  Alpha Eta was founded on February 14, 1927, at the University of Georgia and currently has 1,510 initiates. LC 41 2433 S. R. 890- 1 -Senate Resolution 890By:  Senators James of the 35th, Orrock of the 36th, Seay of th e 34th, Rhett of the 33rd, Harrell of the 40th and others A RESOLUTIONCreating the Senate Zero Waste Study Committee; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, alternative water and solar solutions, such as rainwater recapture, affordable solar power for houses, and greenhouses for organically grown produce and flowers, play a vital role in supporting Earth's ecosystems and protecting, preserving, and restoring the natural environment; and WHEREAS, this state's water, streams, fish, and wildlife will be protected from toxic waste, pesticides, and pollutants if clean water is achieved; and7WHEREAS, clean air can be achieved by the  reduction of transportation by car, truck, ship, airplane, and other CO2 emitting vehicles and by the use of alternative fuels such as electricity, biofuels, and propane gas; and10WHEREAS, every day, valuable resources can be diverted from landfills into economically viable jobs in the State of Georgia; and12WHEREAS, study is needed on establishing methods, standards, and initiatives for the implementation and encouragement of zero waste policies in this state. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE:15(1)  Creation of Senate study committee. There is created the Senate Zero Waste Study Committee. (2)  Members and officers.  The committee shall be composed of five members of the Senate to be appointed by the President of  the Senate.  The Presid ent shall designate a member of the committee as chairperson of the committee. (3)  Powers and duties. The committee shall undertake a study of the conditions, needs, issues, and problems mentioned above or related thereto and recommend any action or legislation which the committee deems necessary or appropriate. LC 41 2433 S. R. 890- 2 -(4)  Meetings.  The chairperson shall call all meetings of the committee.  The committee may conduct such meetings at such places and  at such times as it may deem necessary or convenient to enable it to exercise fully and effectively its powers, perform its duties, and accomplish the objectives and purposes of this resolution. (5)  Allowances and funding.28(A)  The legislative members of the committee shall receive the allowances provided for in Code Section 28-1-8 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated.30(B)  The allowances authorized by this resolution shall not be received by any member of the committee for more than five days  unless additional days are authorized.  Funds necessary to carry out the provisions of this resolution shall come from funds appropriated to the Senate.34(6)  Report.35(A)  In the event the committee adopts any specific findings or recommendations that include suggestions for proposed legislation, th e chairperson shall file a report of the same prior to the date of abolishment  specified in this resolution, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.39(B)  In the event the committee adopts a report that does not include suggestions for proposed legislation, the chairperson shall file the report, subject to subparagraph (C) of this paragraph.42(C)  No report shall be filed unless the same has been approved prior to the date of abolishment specified in this resolution by majority vote of a quorum of the committee. A report so approved shall be signed by the chairperson of the committee and filed with the Secretary of the Senate.46(D)  In the absence of an approved report, the chairperson may file with the Secretary of the Senate a copy of the minutes of the meetings of the committee in lieu thereof. (7)  Abolishment.  The committee shall stand abolished on December 1, 2020.

B. 22- 1 -Senate Bill 22By:  Senators James of the 35th, Rhett of the 33rd and Jones II of the 22nd  A BILL TO BE ENTITLEDAN ACTTo amend Article 10 of Chapter 2 of Title 21 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to absentee voting, so as to provide increased privacy and security to electors in mailing absentee ballots to the board of registra rs or absentee ballot clerk; to remove the elector's oath and other identifying information of an elector from the larger outside mailing envelope and instead include such oath and identifying information on the smaller inside envelope that is mailed inside of such larger outside mailing envelope; to provide for related matters; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes. BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA:8SECTION 1.9Article 10 of Chapter 2 of Title 21 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to absentee voting, is amended by revising subsection (b) of Code Section 21-2-384, relating to preparation and delivery of supplies, mailing of ballots, oath of absentee electors and persons assisting absentee electors, master list of ballots sent, challenges, and electronic transmission of ballots, as follows: (b)  Except for ballots voted within the confines of the registrar's or absentee ballot clerk's office, in addition to the mailing envelope, the superintendent, board of registrars, or absentee ballot clerk shall provide two envelopes for each official absentee ballot, of such size and shape as shall be determined by the  Secretary of State, in order to permit the placing of one within the other and both within the mailing envelope. B. 22- 2 -in Code Sections 21-2-568, 21-2-573, 21-2-579, and 21-2-599 for violations of oaths; and on the face of such enve lope shall be printed the name and address of the board of registrars or absentee ballot clerk. An elector who is confined to a hospital on a primary or election day to whom an absentee ballot is delivered by the registrar or absentee ballot clerk shall then and there vote the ballot, seal it properly, and62 19LC 41 1650 S. B. 22- 3 -return it to the registrar or absentee ballot clerk. LC 39 2011 H. R. 75- 1 -House Resolution 75By: Representative Ralston of the 7th A RESOLUTIONHonoring the life of Mr. Benjamin "Benny" Norton Whitaker and dedicating an intersection in his memory; and for other purposes. WHEREAS, the State of Georgia continues to mourn the loss of one of its most distinguished citizens with the passing of Mr. Benjamin "Benny" Norton Whitaker on August 13, 2015; and5WHEREAS, a native of Gilmer County, Georgia, Mr. Whitaker was born on September 1, 1927, the beloved son of Cecil and Ovaline Norton Whitaker; and WHEREAS, Mr. Whitaker was well known and respected for his leadership and guidance as a Gilmer County commissioner and state representative for the 7th District; and WHEREAS, known as the "Common Man Candidate" and "Common Sense Candidate," Mr. Whitaker diligently and conscientiously served the citizens of Gilmer County as county commissioner from 1972 to 1988 and as a state representative from 1992 to 1998; and WHEREAS, Mr. Whitaker spent 28 years in the produce business, in which he developed a fiscal responsibility which transferred to his leadership as a county and state representative, where he demonstrated great care to save the county money; and WHEREAS, he was instrumental in securing property for a new public library and the site of Dalton State College satellite campus, helped oversee the building of the Whitepath Golf Course and Gilmer County Civic Center, and worked with the state transportation board for the construction of Highway 515; and19WHEREAS, his diligent efforts led to the extension of a natural gas line to Ellijay, the organization of Gilmer County's first official fire department, and the construction of Gilmer County's first senior citizen center; and LC 39 2011 H. R. 75- 2 -WHEREAS, during his tenure with the General Assembly, Mr. Whitaker sponsored numerous pieces of legislation that uplifted the North Georgia mountain communities and state, including the establishment of the Court-Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) program, secured funding for court record modernization, and support of the North Georgia Medical Center; and27WHEREAS, during his time with the General Assembly, Mr. Whitaker sponsored and led the passage of a law requiring visible identification on all vehicles owned by the state; and29WHEREAS, it is abundantly fitting and proper that this remarkable and distinguished Georgian be recognized appropriately by dedicating an intersection in his memory. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED AND ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF GEORGIA that the intersection  of State Route 515 and First Avenue in Gilmer County is dedicated as the Ben Whitaker Intersection. BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Department of Transportation is authorized and directed to erect and maintain appropriate signs dedicating the Ben Whitaker Intersection. BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make appropriate copies of this resolution available for distribution to the family of Mr. Benjamin "Benny" Norton Whitaker and to the Department of Transportation.

LC 117 0745 H. R. 154- 1 -House Resolution 154By: Representatives Glanton of the 75th, Park of the 101 st, Trammell of the 132 nd, Petrea ofthe 166th, Clark of the 98th, and others A RESOLUTIONRecognizing and honoring February 12, 2019, as Korean American Day at the state capitol; and for other purposes.2WHEREAS on January 13, 1903, the arrival of 102 pioneer immigrants to the United States initiated the beginning of Korean immigration to the United States; and WHEREAS the first generation of Korean immigrants established a new home in a new land through resilience, tenacious e ffort, and immense sacrifice,  which became the bedrock for their children and future generations of Korean Americans; and WHEREAS, Korean Americans, like immigrants to the United States before and after them, have taken root and thrived as a result of st rong family ties, robust community support, and countless hours of hard work; and10WHEREAS, members of the early Korean American community served with distinction in the armed forces of the United States during World War I, World War II, and the conflict in Korea; and13WHEREAS, Korean Americans have made significant political, cultural, social, and economic contributions to the State of Georgia, the United States, and the global marketplace; and WHEREAS, more than 120,000 Korean Americans call Georgia home, and Korean is the third most spoken language in the State of Georgia; and WHEREAS, prominent leaders and organizations have helped the Korean American community in Georgia to thrive, including the Korean American Foundation led by President Michael Park, the Korean American Association of Greater Atlanta led by President Il Hong Kim, the National Unification Advisory Council led by Eric Kim,  the Federation of Korean LC 117 0745 H. R. 154- 2 -Associations Southeast led by Kang Sik Kim, the Korean Consulate of Atlanta led by the Honorable Consul General Young Jun Kim, the Korean American Coalition led by Caroline Um, the many Korean American Trade Associations in Georgia, and others; and WHEREAS, for their outstanding contributions to community service, civic engagement, and cross-cultural education, we honor and thank Sh reve Lee, Baik Kyu Kim, Chai Won Kim, Councilman John Park, and Stephanie Cho for their steadfast support for the Korean American community in Georgia; and WHEREAS, Pastor Byeongcheol Han on behalf of the more than 500 Korean American churches in Georgia served as Pastor of the Day; and31WHEREAS, it is abundantly fitting and proper that the innumerable contributions of this outstanding group of Americans be appropriately recognized. NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES that the members of this body recognize February 12,  , as Korean American Day at the state capitol.36BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Clerk of the House of Representatives is authorized and directed to make appropriate copies of this resolution available for distribution to the public and the press.39
